text: (light music)

- I'm Werner Vogels, Chief
Technology Officer of Amazon.com.

I'm thrilled to welcome
Mai-Lan Tomsen Bukovec,
AWS VP of Block and Object Storage.
Thanks for joining us to chat

about the product that
started it all Amazon S3.
- Hi Werner, thanks for having me.
- Tell me about why the simplicity
of S3 is so important.

- Werner, I think the
simplicity of S3 is at the core
of what makes S3 unique.
Simplicity was one of the first tenets
for the service when we built it
and launched it in 2006.

And in fact, if I think back
to the tenets that we put
in place, they all hold true.

And when we build storage,
we think about those tenets
in every decision we make.

We think about how scale
can be to our advantage.

We think about the simplicity
of what we're building

and we think about customer
data is secure by default.

And when you build a
service, over now 15 years,

and you start and you
remain true to those tenets,

you can build something
remarkable for customers

because we're consistent
about what those beliefs are.

And we put it into the
service and we put it

into the operations of the
service and you get S3.
- In 2006, we had no idea
what our customers were going to be.

Now it's just direct
HTTP access to an object.
So how do you do innovation

in a world where you have
literally millions of customers,
all with very unique requirements?
If I think about S3 Select,
or how Athena directly integrates into S3,
how do you do this?

What's the culture behind
that that makes that possible?

- The culture at Amazon, as you
know, is customer obsession.

And so, when we're thinking
about how we evolve S3,
we always start from customer obsession
and what do customers want to do?

Now luckily, we have
millions of customers of S3

and we have over a
hundred trillion objects

with peaks of tens of millions
of requests per second.

And so, we are in this
incredibly unique position
of having such a diversity of use cases

and we have a culture of
listening to our customers.

And so, what that means is
that our customers come to us,

they know that we'll listen
to what the requests are
and they tell us where they're going
with their applications.
And we don't have preconceptions
of existing legacy hardware
or infrastructure in a data center.

We just invent whatever
customers need on top of S3.

And that goes not just for
object storage of S3 and Glacier,
but also for block storage with EBS.
We'll invent it.

If it's not there today
and customers need it
because that's where they're going,
we will invent how to build it
and we'll do it without compromise
to what we think of as table stakes.
And Werner, you and I have talked
about the culture of durability.

We've talked about a
culture of availability.
And we've talked about how important it is

to stay true to those
core elements of security,

of durability, of
availability, and reliability.
And that is also baked into the culture
of S3 and why we'll continue to build that

as the bedrock of what
we provide for storage
in addition to the innovation.
- Thank you very much.
I think we could be talking for hours
about all of the amazing things that you

and the S3 team have
done for our customers.
- Thank you, Werner.
Nice to see you.
(light music)
